description: Enterprise techniques used by FIN6, ATT&CK group G0037 v1.0
name: FIN6 (G0037)

techniques.comment: [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used fake job advertisements sent via LinkedIn to spearphish targets.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used WMI to automate the remote execution of PowerShell scripts.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Comodo code-signing certificates.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has created Windows services to execute encoded PowerShell commands.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used tools like Adfind to query users, groups, organizational units, and trusts.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Pastebin to host content for the operation.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has renamed the "psexec" service name to "mstdc" to masquerade as a legitimate Windows executable.
TRINITY malware used by [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) encodes data gathered from the victim with a simple substitution cipher and single-byte XOR using the 0xAA key.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used RDP to move laterally in victim networks.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used a script to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.
Following data collection, [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.
To move laterally on a victim network, [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used credentials stolen from various systems on which it gathered usernames and password hashes.

TRINITY malware used by [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) identifies payment card track data on the victim and then copies it to a local file in a subdirectory of C:\Windows\. Once the malware collects the data, [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) actors compressed data and moved it to another staging system before exfiltration.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Metasploit’s [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.

[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for various malware it uses, including downloaders known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD and PoS malware known as TRINITY.

[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used tools to exploit Windows vulnerabilities in order to escalate privileges. The tools targeted CVE-2013-3660, CVE-2011-2005, and CVE-2010-4398, all of which could allow local users to access kernel-level privileges.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener.

[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener. [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has also used scripting to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence for its downloader tools known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD.

[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used [Windows Credential Editor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0005) for credential dumping, as well as Metasploit’s [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.
